key_behaviors: Uses AI tools (Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT) multiple times per day for personal tasks
Asks complex, specific questions that would be hard to phrase for a Google search
Requests long, structured outputs such as workout programs, recipes, and step‑by‑step guides
Bounces software‑project ideas off the AI and iterates on them
Copies and pastes code snippets or error messages for debugging assistance
Attempts to have the AI set up a CUDA development environment
Relies on AI to explain technical problems in plain English
Wishes the AI would remember spontaneous ideas and grocery items throughout the day
pain_points: AI becomes “stubborn” and repeats the same suggestions when it cannot solve an ambiguous problem
Fixation on a limited set of answers, especially for technical setup issues like CUDA
Inconsistent keyword detection – the AI follows some words but ignores others
Lack of nuanced follow‑up questions, leading to missed conversational depth
When AI fails, the participant must revert to time‑consuming Google/Reddit/Stack Overflow searches
Concern that deep OS integration could give the AI too much control (privacy/agency worries)
AI interview format feels impersonal and can overlook important nuances
trust_factors: Appreciates that AI can explain technical issues in clear English
Values the ability to correct the AI and have it adjust its answer
Likes the conversational, back‑and‑forth style that feels more like a dialogue than a one‑shot search
desires: An assistant that automatically captures and organizes random ideas, then turns them into actionable game plans
Automatic grocery‑list management that adds items when the user notices they’re missing
Deep integration with native apps (Calendar, Mail, Notes) and possibly the operating system for seamless task creation
Capability for the AI to “continue thinking” on a user’s idea while they are occupied and later present its findings
More consistent, context‑aware follow‑up that picks up on nuanced topics rather than just keywords

verbatim_quotes.quote: The most common types of personal tasks I use AI for are those where I'm asking complex questions that I don't want to type into Google because they're too specific and complex.
I can paste snippets of code that aren't working or error messages, and I can talk through it with the AI, which can explain itself.

It allows me to talk through something without having to generalize the problem. Because in Google, if I have a very specific error, I have to search for something that can pull up a broad range of topics and then search through those articles to see if they address something similar.
The problem with AI, especially with ChatGPT, is that I think it gets fixated on a few answers. If I try all those things and they don't work, it just starts repeating itself.

I'll probably spend a good fifteen to twenty minutes doing this because I feel like with most problems, it is significantly faster to spend fifteen to twenty minutes talking with AI than it is to even attempt to find it on Google.

I think if I had a perfect AI assistant, it would keep track of my random ideas throughout the day. Later, when I'm ready, it would sit down and walk me through all those ideas, breaking them down into game plans to achieve them.
I have a really bad memory, and AI doesn't, so it can keep track of those things for me. Honestly, it being AI rather than just a notes app doesn't make a difference.

I think it's getting to the point where AI is probably going to be built into an operating system. ... It would be harder for it to access other apps, but it would definitely have access to those, and it could create events and track emails.
It feels like there's less pressure. I get to think about my answers before I click record, which is nice.

From a biased perspective, though, you're less likely to have any kind of bias when talking to someone. If there's a person I'm talking to, maybe I'd avoid saying certain things to not offend them ... But with this, I'm going to be exact. I'm going to say exactly what I want to say because you're a robot and you don't have feelings.

unique_insights: The participant sees AI not only as a faster information source but as a memory extension that could autonomously continue working on ideas while they are occupied—a capability they describe as "AI continuing to think by itself". They also highlight a paradox: while they trust AI highly for concrete explanations, they experience a strong need to revert to traditional search when the AI hits ambiguous problems, indicating a trust boundary tied to problem specificity. Additionally, the participant perceives AI interviews as both less stressful and less nuanced, noting that the lack of human emotion removes social bias but also removes the empathetic cues that can enrich authentic communication.
